sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: No—no—you're ſafe enough there—I was oblig'd, you know, to put off her coming for fear of a diſcovery:—But ſee, yonder appears one of the party—and the other, no doubt, will ſoon follow.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: And Arthur O'Donnel will ſoon make another amongſt them.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Suppoſe, then, we conceal ourſelves hereabouts, and obſerve their motions?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: With all my ſoul!

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: But ſee!—what a deuced black cloud there is coming up with the wind!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Well—and what of that?

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Why, an't you afraid, Captain, that it will pepper your fine jacket for you?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Oh! not at all—a ſoldier's jacket is not made for ſunſhine—and mine, I know, won't turn its back to a flying ſhower.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: If that's the caſe—ſtep you behind that pile of hoppoles, while I get on the ſnug ſide of this tree.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Do ſo, little fellow,—ſaith and I have hid myſelf in many a worſe ambuſcade before now. [Concealing himſelf.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Here he comes!—and the ſtorm cloſe at his ſkirts!

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: I don't much like the looks of the weather.—But here am I, ſnugly arrived firſt!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.—(Peeping.)
sp.p: To be ſure, my old Cockatoo, and you are not! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: The ſun ſeems to put rather a black face upon it!—but the hop-pickers are all out of the way—ſurely I can find a little ſhelter for her!—What a lucky opportunity to ſettle matters with the pretty rogue?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: And with me at the ſame time, if you pleaſe. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: Didn't I hear ſomebody?—No!—'twas only a ruſtling among the vines!—Who knows, but the little baſhful huſſey may be half concealed amongſt them? I'll take a peep—and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: There's an abominable old gander for you! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.—(Peeping.)
sp.p: Huſh!—huſh! for the hen bird's now on wing!

div.stage: Enter MISS DI CLACKIT, in her Archery Dreſs.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: How indiſcreet to conſent to this interview!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Indeed, Miſs, and you may ſay that. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: He's a man of honor, no doubt—But, bleſs me, how the ſky lowers!—what ſhall I do, if I'm caught in a tempeſt?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Indeed, Miſs, and you deſerve a good ſopping for your pains! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: I thought I heard a footſtep this way!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Your own, my dear—for you tread none of the lighteſt! [Aſide.
sp.stage: [Miſs Di Clackit goes into the hop-ground.—A tempeſtuous ſhower comes on.—Capt. O'Donnel, and Medley laugh.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Faith they've got a ſouſer!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: So much the better.—To be ſure, and I won't wing the old cock-bird, for croſſing upon my own ſport!

lg.head: AIR XXVIII.— QUARTETTO.
lg.l: MARK! how the cooing pair draws near!
Why, Captain?
—Emily!
—I'm here!
Where are you? Here in half-drown'd ſtate!
Hark, the old ring-dove calls his mate!

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: And now, Matt, muſt you avoid an untimely explanation.
sp.stage: [Sir Walter, and Miſs Di return, and firſt diſcover each other, with aſtoniſhment, as Capt. O'Donnel advances between them unbuttoning his lapels, and careleſsly throwing the rain off his hat.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: What a mighty pretty joke is love in a ſhower! [Looking at them alternately.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul—Madam!—I—can't ſay—that—that I expected the honor of this ducking—to—to meet you here!—

sp.speaker: MISS DI.—(Confuſed.)
sp.p: Nor I—ſir—the pleaſure of catching my death, for the—the—felicity of ſeeing you here!—Provoking wretch!— (Aſide.)—You may think, ſir—

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Oh, palliluh!—I did not hope for the honor of expecting you here—nor I the pleaſure of ſeeing you there— (imitating them)—when you had both contrived the whole farce beforehand—except the happineſs of ſeeing my own ſelf—any where!

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: This is very extraordinary behaviour in you, ſir! [To Capt. O'Donnel.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: And have I caught you out, Couſin Prudery, at laſt? [Exultingly.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: What is it you mean, ſir?—I came—

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: To learn to pick hops according to the articles of war!—but you've got a good ſopping for't—and ſo forth. [Aſide to her.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: There's an honeſt fellow in the world, Madam, who has reaſon to expect better uſage at your hands.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: Excellent!—What ſay you to that, Coz?—Tho' ſhe has fluſhed my pretty game—I can match her—for now I ſhall be able to ſilence her clapper—by poſitive evidence of the fact! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: To you, ſir, I hope I ſhall find time to explain myſelf; and as to my couſin Wiſeacre—

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, the thing is bad enough without any further explanation.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, who may you be—that come in this impudent, bluſtering manner, to poach after a part of my family?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p:
Part of your family?—That's a good joke, my old boy!— (laughing.)—but I'll ſoon ſettle that.—As you're ſuch a dev'liſh fighting fellow—d'ye ſee—why, you may be pleas'd to give me a little account your own ſelf—
for daring to preſume, to ſeduce the miſtreſs of my friend.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.—(Amazed.)
sp.p: I ſeduce!—I—a fighting fellow!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Come, come—make no more words about it:—you'll meet me, my old buck, without further ceremony, on this very ſpot, to-morrow morning, at ſun-ſet—that I may not be compell'd to poſt you—upon ev'ry pole in your own hop-ground.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.—(Looking inquiſitively at him.)
sp.p: Damme, if I think this fellow's any thing but a bully after all!—I'll try him, however— (Aſide.)—Look ye, Captain Bounceabout!—I have ſerved three campaigns, in our county militia, with ſome credit!—and, let me tell you, ſir—I am no more afraid than you, or any other man—of ſire! ſword!—and ſo forth!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: So much the better, my dear.

lg.head: AIR XXIX.— DUET.

lg.l: THE dreadful weapons chooſe, ſir!
No, that I muſt refuſe, ſir;
We'll bring enough,
Then ſight in buff,
'Twill make important news, ſir!
Sword! pike! and hand-grenade!
Will prove us not afraid,
O'Don. With theſe try well to hack me;
Sir Walt. With theſe you think to hack me;
But being brave,
I'll only have
—My honor's ſelf to back me!
—Twelve conſtables

div.head: SCENE XVI.
div.stage: MEDLEY alone, in an Archery Dreſs, with a Bugle Horn.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.—(Laughing.)
sp.p: What would I give, to know how they've ſettled their matters?—but we ſhall have it piping hot when Miſs Di comes on the foreſt, I'll warrant it!—Now to muſter my female troop.

sp.speaker: BOB.
sp.p: Here they come, brother Matt—and a pretty ſhew they make, ſure enough!—
sp.stage: (Female Archers trip in, proceded by foreſt colours—and a paſtoral band of muſic.)

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Well, my ſprightly laſſes!—now fall in—and we'll ſoon march off to the Oak—and ſee who's to win the pretty prize heifer.

lg.head: AIR XXX.— SESTETTO.
lg.l: Oh ſweet Mr. Medley, I ſay!
But mind Mr. Medley, I ſay!
Come dear Mr. Medley, I ſay!
What the deuce is the matter?
How neatly they prattle!
If you keep ſuch a clatter,
What ſweet pretty prattle!
No game on the foreſt will ſtay,
—Oh ſie!
But hence it will fly.
To Old Nick in a trice to get out of your way!
Oh ſweet Mr. Medley, I ſay!
But mind Mr. Medley, I ſay!
Come dear Mr. Medley, I ſay!
Now don't ſtretch your lungs—
We mind not your ſneers:
For to all your glib tongues
Little Huſſeys you know,
Come, pray let us go!
I've only but one pair of ears!
—Pretty dears!

sp.p: "But I ſay, Mr. Medley!"—"Now, dear Mr. Medley!" &c. &c. &c.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Halloah!—why, if you keep up this clatter, I tell you again, that all the game will break the bbounds of the foreſt!—
"Ay, but Mr. Medley—ſuppoſe I ſay, Mr. Medley, &c. &c.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: "Now pray talk a little gently, ſweet ones!
sp.stage: ["Bob, and Kitty Maple, looking at the colours, inſcribed IN MEDIO PALMA."]

sp.speaker: BOB.
sp.p: "An't they very gay, and pretty?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: "Yes, very ſmart indeed!

sp.speaker: BOB.
sp.p: "They were done, ſpick and ſpan new, at London!

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: "Ay—but what's the ſignification of the gold writing, Mr. Bob?

sp.speaker: BOB.
sp.p: "Oh! that's our Vicar's doings—it's Arabac, I believe—but aſk my brother Matt—he can tell you all about it.—

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: "So I will.—Mr. Medley, what does this here mean? [Pointing to the Motto.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: "That there, my love?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: "Yes, that—

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: "Why, as to Archery, it means—that—if—but, perhaps, you'd like a free tranſlation beſt?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: "Dear! I don't care!

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: "Why then the plain meaning is that,—the middle's your mark!—Now for it, girls!—come, Kitty Maple, ſtand you to the right.— (Places her.)—You ought to ſhoot well, huſſey—for your father was always a dead hand at pulling the long bow—

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: "I wonder you an't aſham'd of your wicked ſelf!"

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Here, Betſy Blewit—ſtand by the ſide of her—very well.—S • cky Wheatſheaf, and Jenny Whitethorn, you are next—now let the reſt drop in—two and two.—But where the deuce are the little woodſide nymphs?

sp.speaker: BOB.
sp.p: I'll go and fetch 'em, brother.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Do, Bob!—tell 'em they'll be too late, if they don't put their beſt foot firſt.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Somebody, I ſee, thinks there'll be no ſport, if ſome folks an't here!

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Smartly ſaid, Kitty!—I don't know how they may ſhoot an arrow—but you muſt take care, or ſome folks will hit as far with their ſparklers, as the beſt of you!—Now ſtrike up, pipers!—

lg.l: COME laſſes! Follow me,
With merry glee,
To ſports of Woodland Archery!
With merry glee,
We follow thee,
To ſports of Woodland Archery!

sp.stage: [Medley puts himſelf at their head, and they march off to the repeat of the Chorus.

sp.speaker: DOLLY.
sp.p: Dear, dear!—what can I do?—We ſhall certainly be too late!—and you will not go?— (Speaking to Emily behind)—How can you be ſo unkind?

sp.speaker: BOB.
sp.p:
Come! come! my pretty ones—they are all marched to the ground—with muſic and ſtreamers!—and by
this time her Ladyſhip, Miſs Dinah, is there!—Matt ſent me to look for you!—But where's Miſs Emily?

sp.speaker: DOLLY.
sp.p: There ſhe ſits under that tree—and won't budge an inch, for all I can ſay to her!

sp.speaker: EMILY.
sp.p: I beg you to excuſe me, Dolly!—let me go back—ſay I am unwell!—

sp.speaker: BOB.
sp.p: Now, pray you, Miſs Emily, come along with us—the ſight will be worth nothing without you!

sp.speaker: EMILY.
sp.p: Well, ſince you will have it ſo—proceed—
sp.stage: [Sound of a Bugle horn, within the Foreſt.

lg.head: AIR XXXII.— GLEE.
lg.l: HARK—the Bugle's ſylvan ſtrain,
Calls us to the ſportive plain,
Scene of artleſs love!
Shepherds—faithful tales advancing,
Maidens hearts in tranſport dancing,
Happy may they prove!
How bliſsful then the Wood-nymphs green retreat,
Where Love, and Innocence enraptur'd meet!

div.head: SCENE XX.
div.stage: Tents—Targets—Foreſt Colours, &c.—Female Archers, &c. ranged on each Wing—A Dance, in Character, commences on Miſs Di Clackit's entering, and taking her Seat at the Front of the Foreſt.—At the Cloſe of the Dance, Medley winds his Bugle Horn, and the Female Archers take their reſpective Poſts.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.—(Walking down thro' the ranks.)
sp.p: Are they all here?—are they all ready?—"I'm ſo flurried, and confuſed! [To Medley apart.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: "What's the matter, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: "Would you think it?—My blundering Couſin has diſcover'd me in the hop-ground!

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: "Why, that was a little awkward, to be ſure—but I can manage it, Ma'am—by ſwearing, that I ſent you there on purpoſe to meet him!

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: "My dear Medley—can you, indeed—can you, indeed?—but then if he—

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: "Oh! never trouble yourſelf about it—to be ſure I can—and with a pretty ſafe conſcience, I fancy! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: "As to the Captain—I can eaſily ſet him right myſelf—but I wonder he's not here.— (Walks towards the Female Archers.)—You've pick'd a tolerable ſet—tolerable ſet!—Hold up your head, girl—hold up your head!" [To one of the Female Archers.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: All ready—quite ready, Madam.—Where the deuce can my little huſſies be? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: As they are already—you may ſound the charge, and let the archery commence; though I don't know—

sp.speaker: DOLLY.—(To Emily.)
sp.p: That's her Ladyſhip, Sir Walter's couſin, ſitting alone!
sp.stage: [Medley obſerves them, as the two firſt Archers ſtand forth.]

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Oh, you're come at laſt!—but you've loſt your turns—ſo ſtay here, Dolly, till I call you—for I muſt attend the targets.— (The ſhooting commences croſs-ways at targets placed on each ſide of the Oak.—Medley holding in his hand a card, on which to mark the different ſhots.)

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.—(After the firſt ſhots.)
sp.p:
Pretty well, Kitty—but levell'd a little too high!—Better, much better, Betſey Blewitt—juſt within the
third circle!—very well, indeed!— (After two other ſhots.)—Oh, bad, very bad!— (Two others.)—Excellent!—Well done, Jenny!—within three inches of the bull's eye!—Let me ſee who'll beat that?

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: Who's neareſt, Medley?—who's neareſt?—who's neareſt?

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, Jenny Hawthorn! hollow!— (Shews Miſs Di the mark'd card:—while the Female Archers march to muſic for their arrows, and return to different ſides.)

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Now for it, Dolly—Now, Dolly!

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: Don't rattle and talk ſo faſt, Medley—you confuſe 'em—you confuſe 'em—beſides, if they—

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Oh, worſt of all, Dolly!—No heifer for you, Doll—but you think a good huſband prize enough for one day, I ſuppoſe? [To her aſide.

sp.speaker: DOLLY.
sp.p: Of all conſcience, Matt—I'm content!

div.stage: Enter WILFORD and CAPT. O'DONNEL, near the Oak.

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: Where is the perfidious Emily?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Oh, there ſhe ſits— (Pointing to Miſs Di)—juſt as unconcerned—as if nothing had happen'd at all!

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.stage: (Walking towards Miſs Di, ſtarts back!—turning to O'Donnel)
sp.p: Why add mockery to my diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: Oh, the Captain's here!—I'll pretend not to obſerve him. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.—(On Emily advancing to ſhoot.)
sp.p: Don't be alarm'd, there's a dear.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: But here's a creature, Wilford—here's one— (beckoning to Wilford)—after my own choice. [At this inſtant Emily ſhoots—and hits the centre of the target.—Bugle ſounds.

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: She's won it—ſhe's won it!

lg.head: AIR XXXIII.— CHORUS.
lg.l: TO Beauty's ſhaft the prize decree,
In ſtrains of antient minſtrelſy!

sp.stage: [Wilford and Emily at this inſtant behold each other—ſhe ſinks on Dolly's arm—Capt. O'Donnel runs and ſupports her.

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: Can it be poſſible?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Oh! very poſſible! keep a little back.— (To Wilford.)—It's only a ſmall flutteration at ſeeing me—'twill ſoon be over—ſee how ſhe revives, at the ſound of my own voice!

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: Oh, my Emily!

sp.speaker: EMILY.
sp.p: And do I live again to behold my faithful Wilford?

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Oh, oh! the pretty loſt lamb's own'd at laſt!—the plot will unravel faſt—I muſt to Sir Walter, and by a full conſeſſion, ſecure a free pardon.

sp.speaker: MISS DI.—(Drawing near.)
sp.p: What is the matter?—what is the cauſe of this confuſion?—Pray, ſir—how have I deſerved this uſage? am I ſo alter'd that you don't recollect me—don't recollect me? Surely, Captain—

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Faith and troth—for the matter of that—tho' you have forgot yourſelf—I know you well enough, Miſs Emily, and all your pranks!

sp.speaker: MISS DI.
sp.p: Miſs Emily?—all my pranks? What can he mean? what can he mean?—You well know, ſir, my name is Dinah; and that I am the neareſt relation of Sir Walter Waring—tho' you are all conſpiring againſt my honor? but juſtice, I hope—

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Upon my conſcience, I begin to fancy we are all as mad as wild geeſe! Harkee, Wilford, is it you, or me, that this bewitching rogue has beplundered out of our ſenſes?

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: It is I, my friend, who have loſt mine in love, and admiration!

lg.l: OH tell me, Memory! no more,
What woe in baniſhment was mine—
What pain this lab'ring boſom bore,
Compell'd its treaſure to reſign!
But tell me, Memory—more kind,
The envy'd tranſports I regain;
Record them on my grateful mind,
That not a ſorrow may remain!

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: But where is the ruſtic guardian of my Emily?

sp.speaker: EMILY.
sp.p: Here— (Pointing to Fairlop.)—My kind, diſintereſted protector!

sp.speaker: FAIRLOP.
sp.p: Lackaday! what is all this?

sp.speaker: DOLLY.
sp.p: Oh, father!—Miſs Emily's ſweetheart's found, and this is he!

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: I wiſh I could expreſs the obligations I owe to you.

sp.speaker: FAIRLOP.
sp.p: Pooh! pooh! why do you give the gentleman all this trouble? May I be free enough to ſpeak a word of my mind?

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: By all means!

sp.speaker: FAIRLOP.
sp.p: Then, ſet you, ſir, as much ſtore by this treaſure thro' life— (takes her hand)—as I have done but for three ſhort months—and, truſt a plain man, we ſhall all be ſufficiently rewarded!

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: Generous woodman! Emily, you muſt prevail upon your adopted ſiſter, to attend you to Wilford Lodge.

sp.speaker: EMILY.
sp.p: What ſay you, my dear friend, Dolly?

sp.speaker: MEDLEY.
sp.p: Oh! that's impoſſible, Ma'am—ſhe may ſoon have a houſe full of children of her own to take care of! [Conceitedly.

sp.speaker: EMILY.
sp.p: How is all this?

sp.speaker: DOLLY.
sp.p: The audacious wretch coax'd me into a kind of promiſe this morning;—and I can't find in my heart to be worſe than my word.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Why then, give Dolly the little prize-cow, for a bride's portion—I think, Wilford, you'll not be after making a bull of that now.

div.stage: Enter SIR WALTER, followed by Female Archers, &c.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: Come along, come along! and ſee how I adminiſter juſtice among 'em.—I arreſt you all in my own name!—and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: WILFORD.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, what may be your charge againſt us?— (Smiling.)—It's a bailable offence, I truſt?

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: Yes, if you put in your appearance at my houſe, where, with your conſent, we'll have a merry night on't—and ſo forth. [Shaking Wilford by the hand.

sp.speaker: DOLLY.
sp.p: But perhaps, Miſs Emily—

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.p: Won't reſiſt my authority, when ſhe knows I've a chaplain at hand, who can ſoon bind her over to good behaviour for life.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
sp.p: Upon my conſcience, Sir Walter, but you may command Arthur O'Donnel, eſquire.—Give me your hand, my old buck—it's a pleaſanter thing to draw a cork, than a ſword, with an honeſt fellow, at any time.—But hark ye, little Mittimus, there'll be no need for that Snap-dragon—Miſs Conſumption there, to be one of the party!

sp.speaker: WILFORD.—(To Fairlop.)
sp.p: But, my beſt of friends, with your permiſſion,—we'll tranſplant you to a larger farm, where you may acquire the means of extending your benevolence.

sp.speaker: FAIRLOP.
sp.p: With thanks for your kindneſs, ſir,—as my Landlord's ill-will is blown over, I'll live, and die by my native woodſide! But, before you rob me and Dolly of our pretty companion, and depart—ſtop at our cottage by the way—and, if you can break bread with a lowly man—you ſhall have his bleſſing into the bargain.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: TUNE the pipe, and ſtrike the tabor,
Quickly join their faithful hands;
This is not a time for labour,
While young Joy on tip-toe ſtands!
JUSTICE bids me now befit you,
Blind to all your roguiſh charms;
So I'll certainly commit you—
To an honeſt huſband's arms!
Tune the Pipe, &c.
Fearleſs now our vows are plighted,
Hence the clouds of ſorrow fly!
Love, and conſtancy united,
Thus reſtore a tranquil ſky.
Tune the Pipe, &c.
—Dolly—mind you love me dearly!
—Never fear if you are true:
—Scolding, I ſhall take but queerly,
—Chiding, I ſhall take but queerly,
—Sulky fits will never do!
Tune the pipe, &c.
Marriage faith's a pretty notion,
If you could but change a wife;
But a ſoldier loves promotion—
Not a warm campaign for life!
Tune the pipe, &c.
'Though my Woodland thus you plunder,
Of the ſweeteſt plant that grew,
At the loſs I cannot wonder—
May it better thrive with you.
Tune the pipe, and ſtrike the tabor,
Quickly join their faithful hands;
This is not a time for labour,
While young Joy on tip-toe ſtands!

div.head: ADDITIONAL SONG, By the AUTHOR, introduced on Saturday in the Comic Opera of THE WOODMAN.

lg.l: Court me not to scenes of pleasure,
This fond heart no more must know;
Can it beat to Mirth's gay measure,
All its strings attun'd to woe?
No! the mind by Hope forsaken,
But of Sorrow seeks relief:
Joy no transport can awaken,
Sighs must number out its grief.
